. ἄ ν (see above under subjunctive and compound sentences) is not used by our author with the past indicative, though this is common enough in other books of the N.T. eg. Heb. xi. 2, 9, Gal. iv. 15, Matt. xi. 21, or with the optative, a construction which is found only in Luke and Acts. It is omitted with ὅστις before a sub- junctive in ii. 10, and likewise with ἕως in v, 7. The former construction is very rare in the N.T. but is found occasionally in classical Greek, both verse and prose : the latter is not uncommon in the NT. and is found in classica] poetry and in Aristotle. Instead of ἄν we find ἐάν used with the relative in classical Greek as well as in the N.T., see note on ὃς ἐάν iv. 4.
